From: Dr. Ernie Prabhakar <drernie@...>
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] delivery guarantees
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=231097723; y=l-zhh1_QG0-o2iY2EZS83F2BWNhYZ8a0F7eGuNP_Di_c7rVVupUPOa7fnLuoGbw
X-Yahoo-Profile: sandhyaprabhakar2000

Hi Jan,

On Nov 20, 2005, at 1:59 AM, Jan Algermissen wrote:
> > For example if a GET returns a list of resources how we do the  
> list is
> > complete without some annoyingly superficial xml wrapper.
> If you browser wouldnot understand <ul><li>ITEM</li></ul> iot would
> not have a clue what to  with that piece of the message.

In fact, that would the microformat solution to the problem,  
something like:

MIME-type: application/xhtml
<ol class='xoxo'>
<li><a href="http://example/resource/1">Describe 1</a></li>
<li><a href="http://example/resource/2">Describe 2</a></li>
<li><a href="http://example/resource/3">Describe 3</a></li>
</ol>

That way, a standard XOXO parser would know exactly what to extract,  
and how.   In the 'pure' XML world, I'd recommend using something  
like Atom.   In other words, you need -some- shared semantics in  
order to guarantee anything.

-- Ernie P.

------------
Ernest N. Prabhakar, Ph.D. <drernie at opendarwin.org>
